text: we seem to be in the midst of a revival
of interest in the music of the Swedish
pop group ABBA
or maybe rehabilitation is a better word
because it's finally acceptable to like
all those songs Waterloo dancing Queen
Super Trouper that back when they were
on the radio thirty years ago you would
never admit to actually digging there's
a long-running wildly popular stage
musical Mamma Mia and there's a screen
version of Mamma Mia which stars Meryl
Streep and lots of other people running
around in the Greek sunshine singing and
dancing to those familiar Swedish
English songs but I think that the Abba
reawakening really goes back to 1994
when an Australian movie called murals
wedding written and directed by PJ Hogan
came out and I think that really Mamamia
kind of builds on the popularity and the
spirit of that movie it stars Toni
Collette then virtually unknown in this
country as a young woman named Muriel a
social misfit a sort of ugly duckling
living in a backwater town called
porpoise spit now Muriel is a big Abba
fan she's got all those posters on her
walls she really lives through and in
some ways in the music because she's
pretty unhappy she has this group of
Mean Girls who sort of pretend to be her
friends but they're not really her
friends her father is a corrupt local
elected official and she has a bunch of
fat slovenly brothers and sisters and
it's just a kind of miserable existence
and the only thing that really redeems
it is her love of Abbas music but even
this is held against her her so-called
friends turn on her and brutally dump
and humiliate her as the tears in that
scene show this is a movie that strikes
a very interesting and I think kind of
complicated emotional balance it's funny
and campy and makes fun of its
characters but it's also showing some
very deep and complicated emotions
interestingly enough Abbas music
accomplishes both things that is it's
campy it's excessive it's over-the-top
it's silly you see for exam
when Muriel meets her new friend played
by Rachel Griffiths who went on to star
in Six Feet Under and a lot of other
things they meet and they do a big
over-the-top can't be silly karaoke
performance at a resort of the great
Abba song Waterloo
but one of the most interesting and
satisfying things about Muriel's Wedding
is the way that it uses Abbas music not
only for ironic or camp effect but also
in a very sincere manner from Uriel Abba
is really a way of expressing or getting
in touch with her inner state of mind
and of feeling the movie by taking that
seriously and by respecting that in a
way about her reminds us that pop music
often has that kind of power we use
music even cheesy Swedish pop music to
express things that are very deeply very
very beautiful and very true
